title: How to Dial In Espresso: Complete Beginner's Guide
excerpt: Master the art of dialing in espresso with this step-by-step guide. Learn how to adjust grind size, dose, and brew time for perfect shots every time.
content:
What is Dialing In?

Dialing in espresso is the process of making small adjustments to your grind size, dose, and brew time to achieve the perfect extraction. It's both an art and a science, requiring patience and attention to detail.

The Three Variables

There are three main variables you'll adjust when dialing in:

  • Grind Size: Finer grinds slow down extraction, coarser grinds speed it up
  • Dose: The amount of coffee (typically 16-20g for double shots)
  • Brew Time: Target 25-30 seconds for most medium roasts

Step-by-Step Process

1. Start with a Baseline

Use our calculator to get a recommended starting point based on your equipment and beans. This saves time and gets you close to the target immediately.

2. Pull a Shot and Taste

Pay attention to:

  • Brew time (aim for 25-30 seconds)
  • Flow rate (should be smooth and steady)
  • Taste (balanced, sweet, not sour or bitter)

3. Make Adjustments

If your shot is:

  • Sour/Under-extracted: Grind finer or increase dose
  • Bitter/Over-extracted: Grind coarser or decrease dose
  • Too fast (<20s): Grind finer
  • Too slow (>35s): Grind coarser

4. Repeat Until Perfect

Make one change at a time and pull another shot. Keep notes on what works and what doesn't.

Pro Tips

The biggest mistake beginners make is changing multiple variables at once. Always adjust one thing at a time!
  • Use fresh beans (7-21 days post-roast is ideal)
  • Weigh your dose and output for consistency
  • Keep your equipment clean for better flavor
  • Temperature matters: darker roasts need lower temps (88-91Â°C)
